name: 5,6-dimethylchrysene
Reason: 5,6-dimethylchrysene has a melting point that we will compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The basic unit for our comparison is chrysene, which has a melting point of 100°C due to its planar, aromatic structure. The methyl groups increase the molecular weight and introduce hydrogen bonding potential, which can raise the melting point by approximately +10°C each. The dimethyl substitution also reduces the crystal lattice stability, which might lower the melting point by approximately -10°C. Summing up these changes: Chrysene base (+100°C), two methyl groups (+20°C), and one dimethyl group (-10°C).
